results.snippet: A selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy movies and film series playing this weekend in New York City. * denotes a highly recommended film or series. Ratings and running times are in parentheses. An index of reviews of films...
results.lead_paragraph: A selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy movies and film series playing this weekend in New York City. * denotes a highly recommended film or series. Ratings and running times are in parentheses. An index of reviews of films opening today appears on Page 6. Now Playing * ''A.I.,'' starring Haley Joel Osment, Jude Law, Frances O'Connor, William Hurt and Sam Robards. Written and directed by Steven Spielberg (PG-13, 140 minutes). Mr. Spielberg's new film, a project he inherited from Stanley Kubrick, to whom it is dedicated, is a work of brilliant artifice and profound intelligence. Mr. Osment plays a robot, programmed with the capacity to love, who is sent to live with a couple grieving for their comatose, gravely ill son. The movie's three distinct sections reveal an unsettlingly plausible vision of the future and explore a rich, complex set of emotions and ideas. Mr. Spielberg accomplishes the improbable feat of melding Kubrick's chilly, analytical style with his own warmer, needier sensibility, and the result is an exquisitely layered movie -- the riskiest, most ambiguous, most intellectually challenging fairy tale the director has made to date (A. O. Scott).

results.abstract: William Honan article recalls building rockets with childhood friends Todd (The Freak) Frohman and Morell (Beer) Coon; drawing (M)
results.snippet: WHEN Dennis A. Tito became the first space tourist earlier this year, it reminded me that I, too, had been an amateur astronaut during my formative years before World War II in Bronxville.    In fairness, I should acknowledge that I was assisted by...
results.lead_paragraph: WHEN Dennis A. Tito became the first space tourist earlier this year, it reminded me that I, too, had been an amateur astronaut during my formative years before World War II in Bronxville. In fairness, I should acknowledge that I was assisted by my friends Todd (The Freak) Frohman and Morell (Beer) Coon.

results.abstract: Space shuttle Discovery is poised to take new crew to International Space Station; crew is composed of seven astronauts, including three who are to stay aboard station for at least four months (M)

headline.main: Shuttle Will Ferry New Crew to Space Station

results.snippet: The space shuttle Discovery is poised to take a new crew to live on the International Space Station, a trip that will mark a hiatus in what has been a hectic series of construction missions.    The shuttle and a crew of seven astronauts, including...
results.lead_paragraph: The space shuttle Discovery is poised to take a new crew to live on the International Space Station, a trip that will mark a hiatus in what has been a hectic series of construction missions. The shuttle and a crew of seven astronauts, including three who are to stay aboard the station for at least four months, are scheduled to lift off on a 12-day mission from the Kennedy Space Center in Florida on Thursday at 5:38 p.m.

results.snippet: A selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy movies and film series playing this weekend in New York City. * denotes a highly recommended film or series. Ratings and running times are in parentheses. An index of reviews of films...
results.lead_paragraph: A selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy movies and film series playing this weekend in New York City. * denotes a highly recommended film or series. Ratings and running times are in parentheses. An index of reviews of films opening today appears on Page 6. Now Playing ''AMERICAN PIE 2,'' starring Jason Biggs, Eugene Levy, Shannon Elizabeth and Alyson Hannigan. Directed by J. B. Rogers (R, 104 minutes). This sequel reunites the Michigan teenagers whose clumsy eagerness to be relieved of their virginity fueled the first picture. A lot of the humor in this film consists of references to stuff that happened the first time around, though Mr. Biggs does encounter some novel forms of sexual humiliation, including the painful misapplication of some super-adhesive glue. The rest of the cast members return, some of them quite briefly, for more of the dirty-minded, curiously sweet-natured scenes that are the secret of the franchise's success (A. O. Scott).

results.abstract: Lewis Beale article on SciFi Channel which, while still relying on stalwart classics like Battlestar Galactica and Star Trek, has been, over past two years, reconfiguring itself with original programming, most notably Farscape, First Wave, Chronicle and Lexx; photo (M)

headline.main: A Cable Channel Seeks New Life Beyond Its Niche

results.snippet: IT seems fitting that in the year 2001, the Sci Fi Channel is finally getting it right. And it didn't need a black monolith to point it in the proper direction.    For most of its nine years, Sci Fi has been little more than a cable-television...
results.lead_paragraph: IT seems fitting that in the year 2001, the Sci Fi Channel is finally getting it right. And it didn't need a black monolith to point it in the proper direction. For most of its nine years, Sci Fi has been little more than a cable-television repository for geek culture, the place where old science fiction shows went to die. Whether those shows were classic (''The Twilight Zone'') or kitsch (''Lost In Space'') didn't matter. The channel wasn't really doing anything anyone outside the hermetic world of science fiction cared about. It just sat there at the far end of the dial, barely noticed, like all the other niche networks. Sci Fi Channel, House and Garden Channel, Golf Channel. Who really cared except the true believers?

results.abstract: Kennedy Space Center Visitor Complex in central Florida opens live stage show for children, Mad Mission to Mars 2025; photo (M)

headline.main: Send Your Kids to Mars At the Space Center

results.snippet: A live stage show for children, ''Mad Mission to Mars 2025,'' recently opened at the Kennedy Space Center Visitor Complex. Comedy and music, along with special effects and 3-D computer animation, transform guests into ''astronaut trainees'' on a...
results.lead_paragraph: A live stage show for children, ''Mad Mission to Mars 2025,'' recently opened at the Kennedy Space Center Visitor Complex. Comedy and music, along with special effects and 3-D computer animation, transform guests into ''astronaut trainees'' on a virtual trip to Mars. During the show, scale-size models of planets are brought into the audience at certain distances from each other to simulate the solar system. Staff members choose volunteers from the audience to help demonstrate aspects of living and working in space. Someone gets strapped into a sleeping bag that's attached to a wall, for example, and starts ''dozing'' while wearing a blindfold.
